Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Unified Curriculum and Course Design for Mechatronics and Robotics Engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration: The field of Mechatronics and Robotics Engineering (MRE) has seen continuous growth for almost half a century, and MRE is now embedded in nearly all manufacturing operations. However, it is only within the last decade that educational institutions have started to recognize this field as a distinct engineering discipline, as more universities and colleges offer MRE degree programs. Despite this increased interest, MRE still lacks a well-defined and unified framework for undergraduate degree programs. This project's main motivation is to overcome this challenge in order to train future engineers, with a strong multidisciplinary theoretical and experimental skillset. Graduates with this skillset will be crucial for American competitiveness, because they will be capable of design, development, and implementation of transformative autonomous technologies that improve human health and welfare. This vision will enable MRE to become one of the most impactful disciplines of engineering, attracting diverse and innovative students, graduating professional engineers who will design, develop, and implement transformative autonomous technologies, and improving human health and welfare. To realize this vision, this project proposes to educate the educators by conducting an intensive workshop to prepare current and future MRE faculty to effectively design and teach courses in this discipline. The project team will familiarize participants with the most recent technological and pedagogical advances in undergraduate MRE education through a combination of lectures, active learning, and hands-on lab exercises. This will serve to build a diverse, inclusive MRE community, increase the number and breadth of colleges and universities that offer MRE education, strengthen the MRE offerings at colleges and universities that already teach MRE, and empower faculty to lead MRE curriculum initiatives at their institutions.<br/><br/>The proposed workshop will empower participants to serve as change agents, educational innovators, and thought leaders at their institutions. It will do this by engaging attendees in active hands-on learning of state-of-the-art MRE education concepts, techniques, and approaches. As a result of the workshop, the MRE educational community will be enlarged and engaged, leading to enhanced opportunities for students to become Mechatronics and Robotics Engineering professionals. The workshop will meet several societal goals as well. First, by educating the educators, it will leverage a workshop of 25 participants into an improved education for 10s of thousands of students over time. Robotics, as demonstrated through the media, competitions, and public perception, has immense potential<br/>to draw large numbers of students into STEM fields. These students will in turn contribute to the nationâ€™s long-term economic competitiveness and vitality by developing new mechatronic and robotics technologies and applications. Last, by promoting diversity and inclusivity, the workshop will lead to broader participation in engineering by underserved populations.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There have been many educational efforts around Mechatronics and Robotics Engineering (MRE), but they have not been well integrated or widely adopted. As a nascent community, we continue to re-invent MRE modules, courses, and curricula instead of adopting and improving existing content. With the rapid increase in demand for robotics and automation engineers, now is the time for MRE to coalesce as a distinct and identifiable engineering discipline.

To advance MRE education, this project developed an MRE educators? workshop to empower participants to serve as change agents, educational innovators, and thought leaders at their institutions. It did this by engaging attendees in 3 days of active hands-on learning of state-of-the-art MRE education concepts, techniques, and approaches. The workshop focused on introductory courses while also covering advanced courses, curricula, and hardware and software platforms.

The workshop was conducted virtually, because COVID-2 restrictions did not allow for an in-person event. However, the virtual format proved highly successful. Sets of robotics kits, containing all the hardware needed to teach the material, were developed and shipped to all participants in advance of the workshop. Participants were also given access to on-line materials including software downloads, manuals, lab exercises, project ideas, and 3D printed part descriptions. The on-line resources remain available to the public for their use and adoption.

The project outcomes included:

  • Developing robotics kits for teaching courses in introductory and advanced courses in MRE,
  • Generating a permanent, publicly accessible repository of educational materials,
  • Recruiting a diverse and inclusive set of MRE educators as workshop participants,
  • Presenting a virtual workshop for MRE educators,
  • Contributing to the development of an enthusiastic, diverse, and inclusive community of MRE educators, and
  • The adoption of the workshop materials at over 20 colleges and universities.

Pre- and post-workshop surveys and participant feedback indicate that the project was highly successful in meeting its immediate objectives. Furthermore, the project has contributed to the nation's long-term economic competitiveness and vitality by making it easier for educators to teach mechatronics and robotics to aspiring students, who can be expected to develop new mechatronic and robotics technologies and applications in their professional careers.
